docs.lead_paragraph: Two troubling reports by the Federal General Accounting Office show how difficult it can be for Medicare beneficiaries to get accurate information about their health coverage from their managed-care plans. These plans now provide health care to about 7 million out of 39 million Medicare recipients, a figure that has doubled in the past three years. Yet a check of 16 managed-care organizations found that all of them provided enrollees with either inaccurate or misleading information. Congress revamped the Medicare managed-care program in 1997 to expand choices for beneficiaries, with the expectation that more competition among managed-care plans would provide better benefits and lower out-of-pocket fees. A recent Federal survey found that most Medicare enrollees were satisfied with their health plans. But for beneficiaries to make informed choices, they have to be able to get truthful, understandable information about benefits and the rules of coverage.

docs.lead_paragraph: Health maintenance organizations routinely distribute inaccurate information on benefits and costs to Medicare beneficiaries, and the Government frequently approves such misleading documents, Federal investigators said today. The General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress, said it had examined documents from 16 H.M.O's and found ''significant errors and omissions'' in materials from all of them.

docs.lead_paragraph: A Minnesota fertility clinic has offered a guarantee that men who have vasectomies reversed there will able to produce a pregnancy or it will pay for another fertility procedure. Reproductive Medicine and Infertility Associates of St. Paul said it was the first center to make such an offer, which includes a $6,000 credit to pay for another fertility technique if its vasectomy reversal fails to yield a pregnancy within a year. A vasectomy is a common surgical sterilization procedure that blocks the flow of sperm through a vessel known as the vas deferens.

docs.lead_paragraph: Hundreds of thousands of low-income people across the United States have lost health insurance as an unintended consequence of the 1996 welfare law, Federal and state officials and health policy experts say. In New York City, poor people seeking welfare benefits have often been unable to get Medicaid. New studies show that the problems documented in New York are occurring on a much larger scale around the country.

docs.lead_paragraph: Michele F. Molotsky and Richard C. Smith were married last evening at the Willow Grove Inn in Orange, Va. Ed Tucker, an Orange County (Va.) marriage commissioner, officiated. Ms. Molotsky, 36, is keeping her name. She was until earlier this week the director of field operations for the campaign of Elihu Harris, a former mayor of Oakland, Calif., who was running for the California State Assembly. Before that, Ms. Molotsky was the director of the Mayor's Summer Job Program in Oakland. She graduated from Cornell University.
